Welcome to the third Student Opportunity Bulletin of the 2023-2024 school year.
This weekly bulletin will inform students, parents, and staff in a timely manner about
internships, academic programs, jobs, community service options, and leadership
initiatives, along with other student opportunities in a variety of fields. Please
carefully note deadlines, age requirements, and other pre-requisites for participation.
These various opportunities utilize different formats. Some are in-person, some
remote, and some will involve a hybrid arrangement. Check each program for their
specific format and schedule. Students should consider applying to any that match
their interests and talents. Some program deadlines are fast approaching – please
do not miss them!
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!
There are a number of excellent new opportunities in this issue with fast-approaching
deadlines - including (just to highlight a few):
EVENTS: There is a free virtual ‘STEM Careers Pathway’ panel discussion on 9/30.
There are several upcoming Architecture/Design Fairs for students with an interest
in this field, with the next on 10/1.
BUSINESS/JOBS: Conde Nast offers a Media Industry Internship program for
current juniors – the application deadline is 9/24! The free Rock the Street Wall
Street finance industry/personal finance five-week program for female students takes
place at Stuy on Tuesday afternoons (students work with female professional finance
industry executives) and begins next Tuesday (9/26). The Harvard BOLD
Conference in November for female students had virtual or in-person components.
And the Coder School near Stuyvesant offers part-time paid jobs teaching coding to
younger students – some knowledge of popular CS languages required.
LEADERSHIP/GOVERNMENT:
The National Student Language Institute offers in-person travel (summer) and
virtual (spring) programs for students interested in learning certain new languages.
The Teen Health Advisory Committee welcomes all students interested in public
health to apply for their lower-Manhattan-based advocacy program. And the Youth
Action NYC year-long activist program offers a stipend to its participants.
ART: The Parsons Scholars art & design program for current lower-income
sophomores runs for three years, including summers; it meets on Saturdays throughout
the school year.
STEM: The deadline for the online MIT/BeaverWorks Tech/Computer Science
courses for current 10th & 11th grade female students has been extended to 9/24.
Columbia University’s Synthetic Biology program welcomes all students to apply to
its free weekend virtual introduction to this new field. The free, in-person School of
Interactive Arts Game Design program accepts applications from all students. And
all students interested in engineering, architecture, and construction may apply for the
ACE Mentor weekly partnership with a team of professionals from the Port Authority
– participants work with them on real-life projects Tuesdays at their nearby offices
after school.
RESOURCES/LISTS: STANDOUT maintains an ongoing list of internships &
opportunities for high school students.
